conbody.p: Call the technical support phone number listed on the back cover for further technical assistance or to locate a qualified service agent in your area.

ul.li: Using a manometer, ensure that gas supply pressure is above minimum requirement listed on heater’s data plate and does not drop more than 1.5” W.C. when unit fires.
Ensure that the wire connections to gas valve are clean and tight.
Ensure that the wire connections to flame sensor are clean and tight.
Ensure that the wire connections to spark igniter are clean and tight.
Inspect flame sensor; clean/replace as needed.
Inspect spark igniter; realign igniter gap as needed.
Ensure that an adequate electrical ground to heater has been established.
Confirm that supply gas is turned on.
Using a manometer, ensure that the supply gas pressure is above the minimum pressure requirement listed on heater’s data plate before and during operation.
Ensure that the wire connections to gas pressure switch are clean and tight.
If all above conditions are met, replace the gas pressure switch.

If a Blocked Exhaust error occurs when the blower is running, check for restrictions in the exhaust pipe, including exhaust elbow, condensate drain, and outside termination. Also, check the exhaust pipe installation (size/length) per manual.

If a Blocked Exhaust error occurs before the blower runs, make sure that the pressure switch connections are clean and tight. Check the pressure switch continuity/resistance. The switch should be closed (continuity/0 ohms). Replace the switch if its contacts are open (no continuity).
Other possible causes: high-wind conditions and excessive negative air pressure in building.

If Blocked Intake error occurs before blower runs, make sure pressure switch connections are clean and tight. Check pressure switch continuity/resistance. Switch should be closed (continuity/0 ohms). Replace switch if open (no continuity).
If Blocked Intake error occurs when blower is running, check for restrictions in intake pipe, including intake air connection, outside termination, and inlet condensate drains (if installed).
Other possible causes: High-wind conditions and/or excessive negative air pressure in the building.
Ensure that the wire connections to the upper temperature probe are clean and tight.
Using a thermometer, check the water temperature of the heater.
Use a multi-meter and check for continuity between the two red wires of the upper temperature probe.
If the two red wires are open (no continuity) ,and the water temperature is below 160°F, replace the upper temperature probe.
If the water temperature exceeds 195°F, turn off electric power and gas supply and call Tech Support for further instructions.
Confirm that the water heater is full of water.
Confirm that the powered anode wire connections are tight and free of debris or moisture (for example, rust, solder, metal pipe shavings).
Confirm that a proper electrical ground to the water heater has been established.
Inspect the powered anode(s) and clean or replace as needed.
